items.title: Add support for pre-commit hooks
items.body:
currently I'm using nosetests as a "system hook" [this way](https://github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit-hooks/issues/115).

But nose is also a Python application and it's pretty straight forward to register it as an [official hook](https://pre-commit.com/hooks.html), by basically adding an `.pre-commit-config.yaml` to the root of the repo.

items.title: [Proposal] Expose command line interface to junit plugin
items.body:
nose v1.3.7 supports following options to be overridden from command line argument: 

> --with-xunit
> Enable plugin Xunit: This plugin provides test results in the standard XUnit XML format. [NOSE_WITH_XUNIT]
> 
> --xunit-file=FILE
> Path to xml file to store the xunit report in. Default is nosetests.xml in the working directory [NOSE_XUNIT_FILE]
> 
> --xunit-testsuite-name=PACKAGE
> Name of the testsuite in the xunit xml, generated by plugin. Default test suite name is nosetests.
> 
> --xunit-prefix-with-testsuite-name
> Whether to prefix the class name under test with testsuite name. Defaults to false.

Such option is missing from nose2 until now, which makes the integration with Tox difficult, where multiple environments would generate same xml file. 

I would like to request the feature, allowing junit-xml plugin to expose its option to command line for better CI tool integration.

items.title: \n between param items seems to break pretty-assert
items.body:
When I run this test file:

```py
import unittest

from nose2.tools.params import params


class TestExample(unittest.TestCase):

    @params(('foobar',),
            ('wibble',))
    def test_one(self, value):
        assert not value

    @params(('foobar',), ('wibble',))
    def test_two(self, value):
        assert not value
```

I, confusingly, get different output from each of the tests:

```
$ nose2 --pretty-assert example
FFFF
======================================================================
FAIL: test_one:1
'foobar' (example.TestExample)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):

    assert not value
AssertionError

======================================================================

'wibble' (example.TestExample)
----------------------------------------------------------------------

    assert not value
AssertionError

>>> assert not value

values:
    value = 'foobar'
======================================================================
FAIL: test_two:2
'wibble' (example.TestExample)
----------------------------------------------------------------------

values:
```

items.title: startTest and StopTest called twice for one single test execution in multiprocess mode
items.body:
My [plugin ](https://github.com/and-sm/nose2rt)is using startTest and StopTest methods for API POST requests. Everything works fine in non-multi-process mode in the following order:
1. startTestRun
2. startTest
3. stopTest
4. stopTestRun

But in multi-process mode ( -N 2, two nodes) I've noticed a strange behavior:

1. startTestRun
2. startTest
3. stopTest
4. startTest
5. stopTest
6. stopTestRun.

So, I got doubled POST requests, and it's breaking everything... Can someone explain how to avoid it?

items.title: multiprocess plugin hang for the event can not be serialized.
items.body:
Hi nose2 experts,

I found a problem in the mp plugin that if the event sent cannot be serialized, the `conn.send((testid, events))` will throw exception and cause the process quit. Thus this will exhaust the worker processes and cause the whole tests hang.

```python
def procserver(session_export, conn):
    # init logging system
    rlog = multiprocessing.log_to_stderr()
    rlog.setLevel(session_export['logLevel'])

    # make a real session from the "session" we got
    ssn = import_session(rlog, session_export)

    if isinstance(conn, collections.Sequence):
        conn = connection.Client(conn[:2], authkey=conn[2])

    event = SubprocessEvent(ssn.testLoader,
                            ssn.testResult,
                            ssn.testRunner,
                            ssn.plugins,
                            conn)
    res = ssn.hooks.startSubprocess(event)
    if event.handled and not res:
        conn.send(None)
        conn.close()
        ssn.hooks.stopSubprocess(event)
        return
    # receive and run tests
    executor = event.executeTests
    for testid in gentests(conn):
        if testid is None:
            break
        # XXX to handle weird cases like layers, need to
        # deal with the case that testid is something other
        # than a simple string.
        test = event.loader.loadTestsFromName(testid)
        # XXX If there a need to protect the loop? try/except?
        rlog.debug("Execute test %s (%s)", testid, test)
        executor(test, event.result)
        events = [e for e in ssn.hooks.flush()]
        conn.send((testid, events))       # <== May throw exception and quit the process
        rlog.debug("Log for %s returned", testid)
    conn.send(None)
    conn.close()
    ssn.hooks.stopSubprocess(event)
```

I'd suggest we catch the exception and log it for debugability and keep the process continue to do other works.
For example.
```python
try:
    conn.send((testid, events))
except:
    rlog.exception("Fail sending event %s (%s)" % (testid, test))
```

Does that make sense to you?

Thanks!
Best Regards.

items.title: Setup a mailing list, remove gitter badge, streamline communication
items.body:
This is a project management issue, not a code issue. This issue is partly a public way of showing how I plan to change nose2 communication.

A simple Google Group mailing list would be public, free, and require basically no maintenance. I like mailman better when someone else is on the hook for keeping it running, but Google Groups work well enough. The Jenkins dev community relies on Google Groups.

As part of #423, I'd like to maybe ditch the gitter badge and just link to the mailing list instead.

IM may be more appropriate for immediate communication, but email is much more appropriate to the pace of this project and integrates more directly with people's existing workflows. Signing up for digest mail is easy.

items.title: Tighten up readme a bit more
items.body:
The changes I put forth in #361 have made the readme a bit rambling and confusing for new users, I think.

I also find it unnecessary for a project <1.x to publicly declare that it doesn't support py2.6 as of an arbitrary release.

The readme can be shortened significantly by moving some of this content to the docs pages and simply linking out. A dedicated page for "nose2 vs pytest vs unittest2" would be appropriate.
I _think_ that it's still valuable to call out explicitly, in the readme, that nose2 is a maintenance-first-features-second project at present.

items.title: Explicit testing of module rather than source path
items.body:
Is there any way to force nose2 to treat an argument as a module and try to import it?

The issue I'm having is in a continuous integration environment. I check out the code, install it, and want to run unit tests on the _installed_ module, not the checked out code (specifically to make sure everything needed is getting installed by setup.py).

If I run `nose2 package`, it treats the name package as the directory `package` checked out from source control, rather than a python module `package` that should be imported and have its tests run.  So tests pass because the files are present in source control that could fail once the module is installed.

I have a few workarounds but wondering if there is (or should be) a way to specify that the argument is a module/package?  Alternately can the START_DIR or TOP_LEVEL_DIRECTORY parameters be set to null or disabled to force nose2 to use the Python search paths instead?

items.title: Plugins `junitxml` and `layers` don't seem to interact nicely.
items.body:
I have a set of tests with both the given plugins enabled.

Starting yesterday, with no apparent updates of any code, I get the following error after every run of the whole test suite using `nose2 --config=setup.cfg ...`, whether the run was clean or not:

```
Internal Error: runTests aborted: 'LayerSuite' object has no attribute 'id'
```

I expected no error to be produced here, and the run to terminate successfully with an xml report.


I have tried disabling `junitxml` and the run seems to succeed until another part of my test flow fails because no xml report was produced. If this ticket gains any traction, I will attempt to run it without expecting an xml report and without junitxml to see if I can get a clean run.



I dug through the source for both plugins as well as `unittest.BaseTestSuite`, `unittest.TestSuite`, and `unittest.TestCase`, and my observations are:

1. I think this error is being raised by the `junitxml` plugin, because
    * it happens after all tests have been run, seemingly successfully;
    * there is no xml report produced; and
    * there is some suggestive code (detailed later).
2. I think this error is raised [right here](https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/blob/master/nose2/plugins/junitxml.py#L120-L121), because
    * it's the only codepath I could find in the given packages that calls `test.id()`; and
    * it operates on all `event.test`s with no filtering, which means it might be operating on layer objects.
3. None of the `...Suite` classes define `id`, but `unittest.TestCase` does.


So, I think that we should guard the call to `id()` in `junitxml`'s source. It is somehow being called on a `LayerSuite` object instead of a `unittest.TestCase` object, which causes it to break, I think.

items.title: Coverage fail_under not being respected
items.body:
It appears that failure due to coverage percentages was not fully fixed in #389.

[This MR](https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/pull/395) should illustrate the problem. 

Although using the `--with-coverage` appears to work as expected, using a `nose2.cfg` (or `unittest.cfg` file does not.

When
```
[report]
fail_under = 100
```
is set in `.coveragerc` and 
```
[coverage]
always-on = True
```
is set in `nose2.cfg` nose2 will not return an exit status of 1, even if coverage percentage is below 100%.

After some debugging, it looks like the problem is related to the order in which plugins are run. 

In `nose2.plugins.result.ResultReporter.wasSuccessful()` function will always set `event.success = True` [see line](https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/blob/2d550aa3f9770bfba7a5e2bd905a3f5d4850bdbc/nose2/plugins/result.py#L110). If `nose2.plugins.coverage.Coverage.wasSuccessful()` was called before this, whatever result `coverage` reported will be overwritten.

This would also affect any other plugins that utilise a `wasSuccessful` function to set `event.success`, making plugin execution susceptible to race conditions.

Output from the above test run on (`uname -a`) `Darwin DEVML0195261 17.4.0 Darwin Kernel Version 17.4.0: Sun Dec 17 09:19:54 PST 2017; root:xnu-4570.41.2~1/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64` using `tox`

items.title: Test runs fail due to infintie recursion on Travis; unrelated to changes being tested
items.body:
Both #366 and #380 have been failing, but the failures are (1) not reproducible locally for me (2) appear related to test discovery in eggs, not the proposed changes.

So far, here's what I know:
- #366 and #380 are mild changes to the coverage plugin, but failures don't happen in tests of coverage at all
- Travis hits max recursion depth running in a loop on this line:
  https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/blob/804b78b922bbe064efda4864eadf06e4da279f3a/nose2/plugins/loader/eggdiscovery.py#L62
- Debug logging from that function looks like this:

items.body:
From 
https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/issues/381
>The order of the arguments seem to be non-deterministic as they rely on a set that is expressed in file nose2/session.py line 34. all_ being a set, the plugins order is inconsistent between multiple runs, and so the order of the usage from -h option is non-deterministic either. I recommend replacing all_ by a sorted(all_) in this line.

Haven't tried to reproduce this, just creating separate issue. Would accept a PR with the fix above, preferably  with a test that fails w/o the fix. 

cc: @P-EB

items.title: [Debian] Doc build depends on # of core on build machine (mp)
items.body:
Hey,

I'd like to report two reproducibility issues I met with nose2.

MAINTAINER NOTE: Created https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/issues/382 to track first issue. This thread should be used to track second issue.

The first is with the manpage. The order of the arguments seem to be non-deterministic as they rely on a set that is expressed in file `nose2/session.py` line 34. all_ being a set, the plugins order is inconsistent between multiple runs, and so the order of the usage from -h option is non-deterministic either. I recommend replacing all_ by a `sorted(all_)` in this line.

The second issue is with the documentation of `nose2/plugins/mp.py`. The documentation is built including the default value for processes configuration variable, which is multiprocessing.cpu_count(), and thus depending on the machine where the documentation is built. Also, this function might raise a NotImplementedError. Shouldn't the value be fixed to, let's say, 2, and eventually changed by the user?

A backward-compatible patch is maybe possible:

```
diff --git a/nose2/plugins/mp.py b/nose2/plugins/mp.py
index b712bb3..b6317b4 100644
--- a/nose2/plugins/mp.py
+++ b/nose2/plugins/mp.py
@@ -21,12 +21,31 @@ class MultiProcess(events.Plugin):
     def __init__(self):
         self.addArgument(self.setProcs, 'N', 'processes', '# o procs')
         self.testRunTimeout = self.config.as_float('test-run-timeout', 60.0)
-        self.procs = self.config.as_int(
-            'processes', multiprocessing.cpu_count())
+        self._procs = self.config.as_int(
+            'processes', 0)
         self.setAddress(self.config.as_str('bind_address', None))
 
         self.cases = {}
 
+    @property
+    def procs(self):
+        """Get the appropriate number of procs for self.procs if self._procs is
+        0."""
+
+        if self._procs == 0:
+            try:
+                self._procs = multiprocessing.cpu_count()
+            except NotImplementedError as e:
+                self._procs = 1
+        return self._procs
+
+    @procs.setter
+    def procs(self, value):
+        """Setter for procs property"""
+        if value <= 0:
+            raise AttributeError("Can't set the procs number to less than 1")
+        self._procs = value
+
     def setProcs(self, num):
         self.procs = int(num[0])  # FIXME merge n fix
         self.register()
```

Cheers,

items.title: [Debian] Can you help me with providing a description for the package?
items.body:
Hey,

Me again, with a simple query this time.

The current descriptions of nose2 packages are really short and non-explicit.

I'd like to fix that. For this, I'd need a descriptive paragraph (400 chars max) that describes properly what is nose2 and what purpose it serves.

I tried this, but it looks too generic and a bit short.

```
Nose2 is a testsuite framework that extends the features provided
by unittest in order to make testing easier and more plugin-compliant.
```

Can you help me putting this in good words?

Cheers.

items.title: Add testing for test runs under sdist installs
items.body:
#375 raised this as an issue.

The current testing process only covers `git clone ...; tox`
When `nose2` is installed via a source distribution, it's possible for the contents of the package to differ from the repo. This can result in test failures.

An additional pair of builds should be added to the test matrix, one on python 2.7 and one on python 3.5 (or some other python3) which do something like the following:
```shell
python setup.py sdist
# there are a bunch of ways of getting the version number... this is an easy one
version="$(cat nose2/_version.py | \
    grep '^__version__' | \
    egrep -o '[[:digit:]]+\.[[:digit:]]+\.[[:digit:]]+')"
(cd dist; tar -xzf nose2-${version}.tar.gz)
(cd dist/nose2-${version}; tox)
```

I don't think it's necessary to do this additional testing on every target interpreter version -- just one on py2 and one on py3 should be enough.

items.title: Update the README/Community Discussion/Existential Crisis
items.body:
I don't think we can really say that folks reading the readme these days are

> witnesses at the new birth of nose, mark 2

Most of the other info there is also false.

I am hereby opening the discussion on where are we and where are we going?

Specifically:
* Would we actually recommend people use nose2 over pytest for new projects?
* If so why?
* If not, what is the role of this project?
* Do we want to stabilize to a 1.0.0 at some point? If so, what needs to happen before we get there?

items.title: Get rid of bootstrap.sh (?); maybe add Makefile
items.body:
Working on #357 made me take notice of this script. As far as I can tell, it's a script which invokes... `python setup.py develop`
The rest of it is window dressing. There's no need to call `pip` explicitly since setuptools handles the dependencies, it doesn't actually install sphinx dependencies, and forcing the use of virtualenvwrapper is unnecessary (plain virtualenv works just fine).

I think it should be removed.

---

If there is to be any workflow automation, I would advocate for a makefile with the following targets:
- `make help`: echo each target with description
- `make develop`: create virtualenv, `setup.py develop`, install `docs-requirements.txt`, install `tox`
- `make docs`: submake to run sphinx
- `make test`: invoke `tox`

None of this is necessary, of course, but it beats the pants off of a script that does only one part of this and does it poorly.

This big selling point for this is that someone new to the project can run `make test`, and have that install everything and run `tox` for them.

items.title: Provide more useful message about missing `coverage-plugin`
items.body:
When I invoke `nose2 --with-coverage` when `nose2` and `coverage` are installed, I get this unhelpful error message:

```
$ nose2 --with-coverage
Warning: you need to install [coverage-plugin] extra requirements to use this plugin
```
This message would be more helpful if it included instruction son how to install `coverage-plugin`, or what parameters to load it.

The [Test coverage reporting](http://nose2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/coverage.html) section of the nose2 documentation doesn't mention the need to install `coverage-plugin`, or how to install it, so it looks like the documentation is incorrect.

That documentation also implies that `coverage-plugin` is loaded by default, given that it appears in the [Built-in and loaded by default](http://nose2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins.html#built-in-and-loaded-by-default) section.

items.title: Automatically install per-python version requirements with `pip install nose2`
items.body: As far as I can tell, today `pip install nose2` only installs requirements in requirements.txt even if there are additional requirements for the version of python running in `requirements-x.y.txt`. Looks like these additional requirements are installed by-hand in travis: https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/blob/master/.travis.yml#L14 , should be done in setup.py. We are already checking the version in setup.py, might as well use it for this. https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/blob/master/setup.py#L55

items.title: Switch away from cov-core; maybe use pytest-cov
items.body:
`cov-core` has been a dead project for 3 years. Although it doesn't allow for new issues to be filed, there's [at least one problem with its handling of `.coveragerc`](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41956688)

I would be interested in checking whether or not `pytest-cov` works, since it presumably has most, if not all, of what `cov-core` used to provide.

items.title: Documentation of plugins is unclear: What is the "module name"
items.body:
For the plugins that are not loaded by default, the documentation says: "add the plugin module name to the plugins list in a config file’s [unittest] section". 
To avoid confusion, it would be nice to explicitly state that this module name is dot-seperated starting with `nose2`.

Further more, the individual plugin sections could have the module name somehow highlighted at the beginning (people don't read the docs from start to end)

In the case of "profiler", I tried "profiler" and "prof" before I finally tried "nose2.plugins.prof".

(The first two of course gave the error `ImportError: No module named profiler` and `ImportError: No module named prof` respectively)

items.title: No easy way to define and utilize a reusable layer (with tests) in Such
items.body:
I've been digging around the source code and haven't been able to find a clean way to define a labelled section of layers, sublayers, and tests that I can reuse in multiple places (although, I may have missed it). I'm currently trying to write some functional tests for a website, and at many points, I'll have to run the same exact tests, so being able to define those layers ahead of time and just drop them in wherever they need to be would be incredibly useful.

Ideally, I'd like to have something like this be spat out:

```
MainPage
  NavigationBar
    AboutUsLink
      displayed ... ok
    SubMenu
      Default
        MenuItem1Link
          not displayed ... ok
      Expanded
        MenuItem1Link
          displayed ... ok
OtherPage
  NavigationBar
    AboutUsLink
      displayed ... ok
    SubMenu
      Default
        MenuItem1Link
          not displayed ... ok
      Expanded
        MenuItem1Link
          displayed ... ok
```

where `NavigationBar` is a collection of layers, sublayers, and tests that is being reused in both `MainPage` and `OtherPage`.

I've tried a number of methods, but nothing seems to be working. Is there a way to do this? And if not, maybe this is a good opportunity to increase the flexibility of `Such`.

items.title: Add version information to module
items.body:
It's helpful when checking dependencies programmatically or for a developer to be able to retrieve version information from the modules `__version__` attribute (see [PEP396](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0396/)).

Our use case is a `check_dependencies.py` script that the developer can run to verify they have all necessary packages installed and that they're the correct version.

Exists something equivalent here?

items.title: Suggested change to docs - how to do .ini/.cfg keys as lists
items.body:
Had to do a trial by error to figure out how to have coverage-report do both term-missing & html.

Perhaps adding an example for proper config values would help someone else out?

Did the following until I figured it out.

```
;coverage-report = [term-missing,html]
; ['[term-missing,html]']

;coverage-report = term-missing, html
;['term-missing, html']

;coverage-report = term-missing html
; ['term-missing html']

;coverage-report: term-missing
;html
; exception, config parse error "\nthtml"

coverage-report =   term-missing
                    html
; This worked
```

items.title: coverage: fail_under and non-zero exit code
items.body:
I may be doing something wrong, but it looks like the `fail_under` param in coverage is not being respected by nose2. I have this set to 100, but still get a zero return code from nose2.

For CI, etc., it would be helpful to see a non-zero return code for inadequate coverage.

items.title: multiprocess plugin hanging during test execution
items.body:
We've encountered an issues lately that is quite confusing. Our CI server runs tests in parallel with 4 processes. However, it has started hanging every once in awhile. Some digging has allowed us to create an example TestSuite that highlights this behavior:

``` python
import unittest

class ThreeTests(unittest.TestCase):

    def test_one(self):
        pass

    def test_two(self):
        pass

    def test_three(self):
        pass
```

running the following will show nose2 hang:

``` bash
nose2 three_tests --plugin=nose2.plugins.mp -N 4
```

The hypothesis is that when running the tests in bulk (10,000+ tests in many suites), that a test suite with three tests is firing at times that is not initially sending an event to the process? 

We've done some playing with where the test suite is flattened and distributed but these seems to have consequences on overall test run times: https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/blob/master/nose2/plugins/mp.py#L75

``` python
        # send one initial task to each process
        for proc, conn in procs:
            if not flat and self.procs_initialized is True:
                break
            if not flat and self.procs_initialized is False:
                conn.send(None)
                continue
            caseid = flat.pop(0)
            conn.send(caseid)
        self.procs_initialized = True
```

Anyone have any other ideas?

items.title: exception when using layers with testtools result class
items.body:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "[...]/custom_repos/nose2/nose2/main.py", line 271, in runTests
    self.result = runner.run(self.test)
  File "[...]/custom_repos/nose2/nose2/runner.py", line 53, in run
    executor(test, result)
  File "[...]/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pygash/plugins/testtools_.py", line 115, in executor
    return suite.run(result)
  File "[...]/lib/python2.7/site-packages/unittest2/suite.py", line 126, in run
    test(result)
  File "[...]/lib/python2.7/site-packages/unittest2/suite.py", line 87, in __call__
    return self.run(*args, **kwds)
  File "[...]/custom_repos/nose2/nose2/suite.py", line 27, in run
    self.handle_previous_test_teardown(result)
  File "[...]/custom_repos/nose2/nose2/suite.py", line 56, in handle_previous_test_teardown
    delattr(result, '_previousTestClass')
AttributeError: _previousTestClass
```

seems that `_previousTestClass` is a class attribute, which is why we cannot delete it at the instance level. Weirdly, the result class directly inheritates from the `unittest` one, so we _should_ also see this issue in our tests:

``` python
class TestResult(unittest.TestResult):
    # [...]
```

items.title: junit-xml always add logs in system_err
items.body:
This is really strange because logs are typically not outputted in stderr. 
In nosetests we did not have logs in case of successful test but now they are always displayed as system_err. 

May it be possible to output them in system_out instead ?

In the testOutcome handler just replace system_err with this code ...

``` python
        system_out = ET.SubElement(testcase, 'system-out')
        system_out.text = string_cleanup(
            '\n'.join(event.metadata.get('logs', '')),
            self.keep_restricted
        )

```

items.title: junit-xml does not output generated tests parameters
items.body:
I use generated tests with meaningfull parameters and I wish I could see them exported in junit-xml report. 

The patch looks pretty simple (junitxml.py): 

``` python
    def testOutcome(self, event):
        """Add test outcome to xml tree"""
        test = event.test
        testid_lines = test.id().split('\n')
        testid = testid_lines[0]
        # split into module, class, method parts... somehow
        parts = testid.split('.')
        classname = '.'.join(parts[:-1])
        method = parts[-1]
        if len(testid_lines) > 1:
            method = '%s:' % method + ':'.join(testid_lines[1:])
```

With this one we can have all parameters as requested.

items.title: load test failure is hidden if import fails in a subpackage
items.body:
Reproducing:

```
mkdir a_subpackage
touch a_subpackage/__init__.py
cat << EOF > a_subpackage/test_foo.py
import doesnotexist
def test_something():
   pass
EOF
nose2 a_subpackage.test_foo
```

output:

```
E
======================================================================
ERROR: a_subpackage.test_foo (nose2.loader.LoadTestsFailure)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'test_foo'

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.000s

FAILED (errors=1)
```

Expected:

```
E
======================================================================
ERROR: a_subpackage.test_foo (nose2.loader.LoadTestsFailure)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
ImportError: No module named doesnotexist

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.000s

FAILED (errors=1)
```

The workaround, when that happens is to try to import the module directly do get the stacktrace:

```
python -m a_subpackage.test_foo
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/runpy.py", line 162, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", fname, loader, pkg_name)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/runpy.py", line 72, in _run_code
    exec code in run_globals
  File "/home/corentih/a_subpackage/test_foo.py", line 1, in <module>
    import doesnotexist
ImportError: No module named doesnotexist
```

The reason of this is in `nose2/utils.py`:

``` python
def object_from_name(name, module=None):
    """Import object from ``name``"""
    parts = name.split('.')
    if module is None:
        parts_copy = parts[:]
        while parts_copy:
            try:
                print 'importing {}'.format('.'.join(parts_copy))
                module = __import__('.'.join(parts_copy))
                break
            except ImportError:
                print 'failed'
                del parts_copy[-1]
                if not parts_copy:
                    raise
        parts = parts[1:]

    parent = None
    obj = module
    for part in parts:
        # The "AttributeError" occurs here because the module `a_subpackage` has no attribute `test_foo` since it couldnt be imported
        parent, obj = obj, getattr(obj, part)
    return parent, obj
```

I added a few prints to visualize what happens. Output when running `nose2 a_subpackage.test_foo`:

```
importing a_subpackage.test_foo
failed                            ==> Here we should raise an exception, instead of continuing, but how to determine this is a legit import failure?
importing a_subpackage

E
======================================================================
ERROR: a_subpackage.test_foo (nose2.loader.LoadTestsFailure)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'test_foo'

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.000s

FAILED (errors=1)
```

I don't really know how to fix that, and it's pretty annoying. I think it relates to https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/issues/109

@leth any idea? I'm asking because you seem to have looked at how `LoadTestFailure`s are reported, recently (https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/commit/255074d06ed8f5ad3daaa8ea5ffc5a9f090fb830)

items.title: Module level coverage missing
items.body:
Say I have the coverage plugin installed, configured, and enabled and I have a simple test:

``` .py
from unittest import TestCase

from my_module import returns_42

class MyTest(TestCase):
    def test_it(self):
        self.assertEqual(returns_42(), 42)
```

The test passes and all is good until I have a look at coverage report. The module level coverage is absent, but the function level coverage is present:

![coverage](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1094000/10264286/a829f566-69cc-11e5-80a7-5e8ceadeea37.png)

According to [this StackOverflow question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9155854/getting-pythons-coverage-py-to-gather-coverage-for-the-module-that-imports-it), this behavior implies that coverage isn't being collected until _after_ the test starts.

A work around would be to do something like this:

``` .py
from unittest import TestCase

class MyTest(TestCase):
    def test_it(self):
        from my_module import returns_42
        self.assertEqual(returns_42(), 42)
```

which gives me the coverage I expect:

![coverage_i_expect](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1094000/10264315/5916960e-69cd-11e5-97de-57a17111fea6.png)

however, that's not what I would consider an ideal solution. Is there an option or a setting that I am missing to fix this? Is there something else that I am missing?

items.title: logCapture plugin prints logs for non-failed tests
items.body:
The [docs](http://nose2.readthedocs.org/en/latest/_modules/nose2/plugins/logcapture.html) say:

> Capture log messages during test execution, appending them to the error reports of failed tests.

In my case the captured logs are printed even if a test didn't fail:

```
$ ./runtests.sh -v tests.test_application.Test.test_not_found
test_not_found (tests.test_application.Test) ... ERROR   Template not found: not_found/cfa.html
ok

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.668s

```

Configuration file:

```
[log-capture]
log-level = WARNING
```

Looking at the plugin code I didn't find any place where it's checked that the test failed.

items.title: Migrating from nose to nose2
items.body:
Hi all, I apologize for opening this here but I could not find any forums/IRC channels or other support/discussion areas for nose2.

Im trying to migrate a project that I have which was using nose to using nose2 with coverage reporting (branch coverage enabled). When using nose I get 100% coverage on my project but in migrating to nose2 I have run into issues which I have narrowed down to the way nose2 interacts with coverage and the apparent need for coverage specific configuration files with nose2 that I ddint need with nose before (as far as I can tell).

I have the following directory structure for my project:

```
.
├── python
│   ├── mainmodule
│   │   ├── api
│   │   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   │   ├── mod1.py
│   │   │   ├── mod2.py
│   │   │   └── resource
│   │   │       ├── mod1.py
│   │   │       ├── formatter
│   │   │       │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   │       │   ├── mod1.py
│   │   │       │   └── mod2.py
│   │   │       ├── __init__.py
│   │   │       └── mod2.py
│   │   └── __init__.py
│   └── test
│       ├── __init__.py
│       └── unit
│           ├── __init__.py
│           └── mainmodule
│               ├── api
│               │   ├── __init__.py
│               │   ├── mod1_test.py
│               │   ├── mod2_test.py
│               │   └── resource
│               │       ├── mod1_test.py
│               │       ├── formatter
│               │       │   ├── __init__.py
│               │       │   ├── mod1_test.py
│               │       │   └── mod2_test.py
│               │       ├── __init__.py
│               │       └── mod2_test.py
│               └── __init__.py
├── setup.cfg
├── setup.py
├── unittest.cfg    # added for nose2, did not need for nose
├── .coveragerc   # added for nose2, did not need for nose
└── VERSION
```

With nose I am able to run the following and get 100% coverage with branch output:

```
python setup.py nosetests --cover-branches --cover-package mainmodule --rednose -s -v --with-coverage
```

It gives the report as:

```
Name                                         Stmts   Miss Branch BrMiss  Cover   Missing
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
mainmodule                                     2      0      0      0   100%   
mainmodule.api                                 0      0      0      0   100%   
mainmodule.api.mod1                           29      0     12      0   100%   
mainmodule.api.mod2                           79      0     18      0   100%   
mainmodule.api.resource                        0      0      0      0   100%   
mainmodule.api.resource.mod1                  60      0     20      0   100%   
mainmodule.api.resource.formatter              0      0      0      0   100%   
mainmodule.api.resource.formatter.mod1        18      0      8      0   100%   
mainmodule.api.resource.formatter.mod2        23      0     12      0   100%   
mainmodule.api.resource.mod2                  32      0      8      0   100%   
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
TOTAL                                          243      0     78      0   100%   

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
31 tests run in 2.3 seconds (31 tests passed)
```

Using nose2 I had to add `unittest.cfg` and `.coveragerc` to even get a report close to the above but I still have problems with it reporting lines missing that are almost impossible to have been missed (pretty much identical to the issue [here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/22146864/pytest-2-5-2-coverage-reports-missing-lines-which-must-have-been-processed)).

unittest.cfg:

```
[coverage]
always-on       = True
coverage-report = annotate
                  html
                  term
                  term-missing
                  xml

[unittest]
code-directories   = python
plugins            = nose2.plugins.coverage
                     nose2.plugins.junitxml
start-dir          = python
test-file-pattern  = *_test.py
test-method-prefix = test_
```

.coveragerc:

```
[run]
branch  = True
include = python/mainmodule/*
omit    = python/test/*
          test_*.*
source  = python
timid   = True
```

Running `nose2` produces the following report:

```
...............................
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 31 tests in 1.970s

OK
---------- coverage: platform linux2, python 2.7.6-final-0 -----------
Name                                                Stmts   Miss Branch BrMiss  Cover   Missing
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
python/mainmodule/api/mod1                           29      7     12      0    83%   8-33, 73, 90
python/mainmodule/api/mod2                           79     26     18      0    73%   17-116, 169, 223
python/mainmodule/api/resource/mod1                  60     23     20      0    71%   9-38, 74, 103, 113-135, 150-221, 247
python/mainmodule/api/resource/formatter/mod1        18      3      8      0    88%   9-13
python/mainmodule/api/resource/formatter/mod2        23      4     12      0    89%   10-15
python/mainmodule/api/resource/mod2                  32     12      8      0    70%   9-34, 59-60, 105
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
TOTAL                                                 241     75     78      0    76%   
Coverage annotated source written next to source
Coverage HTML written to dir htmlcov
Coverage XML written to file coverage.xml
```

The misses here are all stuff that is almost impossible to miss (import/class/def lines mostly as shown in the stackoverflow link). The output format of the report is also using fully qualified paths as oppposed to the module names which I prefer better than the path and I have no idea why its like this.

My question is basically is there any documentation on how to migrate some of core nose coverage options into nose2 equivalents? The processes seem to be quite different and im not quite sure if I have it configured incorrectly or if Im missing config options.

items.title: Layers is incompatible with setuptools test
items.body:
Layers crashes when tests are run from setuptools via nose2.collector.collector 

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 8, in <module>
    test_suite="nose2.collector.collector",
  File "C:\Python34\lib\distutils\core.py", line 149, in setup
    dist.run_commands()
  File "C:\Python34\lib\distutils\dist.py", line 955, in run_commands
    self.run_command(cmd)
  File "C:\Python34\lib\distutils\dist.py", line 974, in run_command
    cmd_obj.run()
  File "c:\Projects\tdd_with_python\lib\site-packages\setuptools\command\test.py", line 146, in run
    self.with_project_on_sys_path(self.run_tests)
  File "c:\Projects\tdd_with_python\lib\site-packages\setuptools\command\test.py", line 127, in with_project_on_sys_path
    func()
  File "c:\Projects\tdd_with_python\lib\site-packages\setuptools\command\test.py", line 167, in run_tests
    testRunner=self._resolve_as_ep(self.test_runner),
  File "C:\Python34\lib\unittest\main.py", line 93, in __init__
    self.runTests()
  File "C:\Python34\lib\unittest\main.py", line 244, in runTests
    self.result = testRunner.run(self.test)
  File "C:\Python34\lib\unittest\runner.py", line 168, in run
    test(result)
  File "C:\Python34\lib\unittest\suite.py", line 87, in __call__
    return self.run(*args, **kwds)
  File "C:\Python34\lib\unittest\suite.py", line 125, in run
    test(result)
  File "C:\Python34\lib\unittest\suite.py", line 87, in __call__
    return self.run(*args, **kwds)
  File "C:\Python34\lib\unittest\suite.py", line 125, in run
    test(result)
  File "C:\Python34\lib\unittest\case.py", line 622, in __call__
    return self.run(*args, **kwds)
  File "c:\Projects\tdd_with_python\lib\site-packages\nose2\collector.py", line 13, in run
    ok = self._collector(result_)
  File "c:\Projects\tdd_with_python\lib\site-packages\nose2\collector.py", line 27, in _collector
    rslt = rnr.run(test)
  File "c:\Projects\tdd_with_python\lib\site-packages\nose2\runner.py", line 45, in run
    self.session.hooks.startTestRun(event)
  File "c:\Projects\tdd_with_python\lib\site-packages\nose2\events.py", line 224, in __call__
    result = getattr(plugin, self.method)(event)
  File "c:\Projects\tdd_with_python\lib\site-packages\nose2\plugins\layers.py", line 22, in startTestRun
    event.suite = self._makeLayerSuite(event)
  File "c:\Projects\tdd_with_python\lib\site-packages\nose2\plugins\layers.py", line 26, in _makeLayerSuite
    event.suite, self.session.testLoader.suiteClass)
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'suiteClass'
```

Layers uses `session.testLoader` which is set in `PluggableTestProgram.parseArgs`. This field is not set when tests are executed via the `nose2.collector.collector` entry point.

items.title: logs printed twice
items.body:
I'm not sure if this is a bug or if I'm just misunderstanding something.

Here is a simple example : 

``` python
# test.py
import logging

stream_handler = logging.StreamHandler()
stream_handler.setFormatter(logging.Formatter('%(asctime)s :: %(levelname)s :: %(name)s :: %(message)s'))
log = logging.getLogger(__name__)
log.addHandler(stream_handler)
log.setLevel(logging.INFO)


def fun_test():
    log.info('Running fun_test !')
```

```
$ nose2 test
2015-01-02 11:00:30,421 :: INFO :: test :: Running test_foo!          
INFO:test:Running test_foo!                                           
.                                                                     
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.000s                                                  

OK                                                                    
```

How can I have the logs printed only once ? There is a doc about the `logcapture` plugin which provides a `--log-capture` option, but the option is not available :

```
$ nose2 -h
usage: nose2 [-s START_DIR] [-t TOP_LEVEL_DIRECTORY] [--config [CONFIG]]
             [--no-user-config] [--no-plugins] [--plugin PLUGINS]
             [--exclude-plugin EXCLUDE_PLUGINS] [--verbose] [--quiet]
             [--log-level LOG_LEVEL] [-B] [-D] [--coverage PATH]
             [--coverage-report TYPE] [--coverage-config FILE] [-C] [-F] [-h]
             [testNames [testNames ...]]

positional arguments:
  testNames

optional arguments:
  -s START_DIR, --start-dir START_DIR
                        Directory to start discovery ('.' default)
  -t TOP_LEVEL_DIRECTORY, --top-level-directory TOP_LEVEL_DIRECTORY, --project-directory TOP_LEVEL_DIRECTORY
                        Top level directory of project (defaults to start dir)
  --config [CONFIG], -c [CONFIG]
                        Config files to load, if they exist. ('unittest.cfg'
                        and 'nose2.cfg' in start directory default)
  --no-user-config      Do not load user config files
  --no-plugins          Do not load any plugins. Warning: nose2 does not do
                        anything if no plugins are loaded
  --plugin PLUGINS      Load this plugin module.
  --exclude-plugin EXCLUDE_PLUGINS
                        Do not load this plugin module
  --verbose, -v         print test case names and statuses
  --quiet
  --log-level LOG_LEVEL
                        Set logging level for message logged to console.
  -h, --help            Show this help message and exit

plugin arguments:
  Command-line arguments added by plugins:

  -B, --output-buffer   Enable output buffer
  -D, --debugger        Enter pdb on test fail or error
  --coverage PATH       Measure coverage for filesystem path (multi-allowed)
  --coverage-report TYPE
                        Generate selected reports, available types: term,
                        term-missing, annotate, html, xml (multi-allowed)
  --coverage-config FILE
                        Config file for coverage, default: .coveragerc
  -C, --with-coverage   Turn on coverage reporting
  -F, --fail-fast       Stop the test run after the first error or failure
```

six version still locked to >=1.1,<1.4 in python 3.4
items.body:
Hi, I'm having some trouble with nose2 as it forces six to be 1.3.0

This is weird, as I have seen work has been done to support 1.7.3

Versions:
- python (python3) 3.4.1
- pip (pip3) 1.5.6
- six: 1.7.3

That is in Mac OS with Homebrew, but the same happens in Ubuntu with python 3.4.0 and pip 1.5.4 so it isn't platform-specific.

Running `pip3 install nose2` will include the following message (installing nose2 version 0.4.7):

> Downloading/unpacking six>=1.1,<1.4 (from nose2)

And will downgrade six to version 1.3.0. If I upgrade six back to 1.7.3 then nose2 won't run:

> pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: six>=1.1,<1.4

Is this a bug or am I missing something?

items.title: Such DSL: setup runs out of order when using @it.uses
items.body: I have an example here ([gist](https://gist.github.com/lukeorland/d4534a20241d7b5280b0)) of an internal layer's tests being run before its setup when the setup is defined in the `Layer` class and then accessed via `@it.uses(Layer)`.

items.title: such and normal test cases: mixed up call order of it.has_setup and setUpClass
items.body:
As it is a little bit complicated to explain, I have created a working example as a gist: https://gist.github.com/jrast/109f70f9b4c52bab4252

I have several "normal" UnitTestCases and a few such tests. The problem is that the setUpClass calls are mixed up with the setup calls in such tests, as can be seen in the log file. The documentation states that I can not use Layer and setUpClass functions in the same TestCase, but it does not state that I cant use them side by side wich is the case in my example. So the question is: is this a bug or is there a missing hint in the documentation.

Either way I think this is a dangerous behaviour because test fixtures made in a setup call can be modified from outside of the current test case wich can lead to very unpredictable behaviour and wrong test results. One example of wrong behaviour is shown with the UniqueResource class wich is locked in the setup functions and unlocked in the teardown functions. As soon as the calls get mixed up a exception is thrown because the resource is already locked.

I realy hope this is not just a missing hint/warning in the docs, otherwise I have to rethink about how to structure my tests...

items.title: [profile plugin] hotshot is broken
items.body:
In Python there is a 10 years old bug and I stumbled upon it: http://bugs.python.org/issue900092

And quote from python [docs](https://docs.python.org/2/library/hotshot.html) about hotspot:

```
For common usage it is recommended to use cProfile instead. hotshot is not maintained and might be removed from the standard library in the future.
```

So, my proposal is to replace hotspot by cProfile (or something else, actually I'm not familiar with this part of python)

items.title: MP plugin does't call startSubprocess in subprocess
items.body:
My very quick diagnosis is:

In [mp.py](https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/blob/master/nose2/plugins/mp.py):
- The new hook methods are registered on [line 27](https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/blob/master/nose2/plugins/mp.py#L27)
- However that is only called in the master process
- Hence, when in the subprocess on [line 197](https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/blob/master/nose2/plugins/mp.py#L197) we register the plugins, the session doesn't know to look for `startSubprocess` (or `stopSubprocess` for that matter)
- Hence when it tries to dispatch it on [line 202](https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2/blob/master/nose2/plugins/mp.py#L202) it won't call the plugins
